user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init_mem_pools_:
```c
void
MHD_init_mem_pools_ (void)
{
#ifdef MHD_SC_PAGESIZE
  long result;
  result = sysconf (MHD_SC_PAGESIZE);
  if (-1 != result)
    MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) result;
  else
    MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_;
#elif defined(_WIN32)
  SYSTEM_INFO si;
  GetSystemInfo (&si);
  MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) si.dwPageSize;
#else
  MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t) MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_;
#endif /* _WIN32 */
  mhd_assert (0 == (MHD_sys_page_size_ % ALIGN_SIZE));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_init_mem_pools_:
#define MHD_SC_PAGESIZE _SC_PAGE_SIZE
...
static size_t MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t)
#if defined(MHD_USE_PAGESIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGESIZE;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGE_SIZE;
#else  /* ! MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC */
                                   _MHD_FALLBACK_PAGE_SIZE
...
#define MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_ _MHD_FALLBACK_PAGE_SIZE
...
#define ALIGN_SIZE (2*sizeof(void*))
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.17 concerns the use of the C <string.h> functions (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) and ensuring their pointer parameters do not cause out-of-bounds accesses. The supplied function MHD_init_mem_pools_ and the related macros/definitions do not invoke any of those standard string-handling functions. The function only calls sysconf (or GetSystemInfo on Windows), performs integer-to-size_t casting and assignment, and uses mhd_assert which is defined as a no-op. The macros shown (MHD_SC_PAGESIZE, MHD_DEF_PAGE_SIZE_, ALIGN_SIZE, etc.) do not expand to string.h calls. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that are relevant for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
